The new Institute of Law Building will be started sometime in the
next few months, according to Dr.
Cook. It will be open for use in
the fall of 1930, and the students
and professors will be ready to
start their work of Law Research
in the new building.
New Structure

A new structure is to be erected,
which cost $450,000. This will be
the home of the Institute of Law
and will be situated opposite the
Carrol mansion. This has been
made possible through the kindness
of an anonymous donor. The laboratories of the research workers
in law will consist of comfortable
studies.
Dr. Cook says, "the object of
the Institute will be to look into the
legal system of the United States
and find out whether or not our
laws prohibit the things which
should be prohibited and allow the
things which should be allowed."
The newly printed pamphlet of
the Institute, speaking of the Johns
Hopkins University says:
"It has commenced the two-fold
task, first of investigating the effect
of specific laws and legal procedures,
and, second, of securing knowledge
of economic and other conditions
which should influence the development of law."

The Johns Hopkins football
eleven opened its home-game season
for 1929 in a rather inauspicous
manner at Homewood last Saturday by suffering a 7 to 0 defeat at the hands of the Juniata

by unexpected sharp work by the
visitors. Chief credit for the upset
may be laid to the fine work of
Captain Andrews, who directed the
Pennsylvanians, and sparkled on
the offensive with some high-grade
ball carrying. It was Andrews who
scored the touchdown of the game
and it was he who was continually
boring his way into Hopkins' territory on straight bucks, off-tackle
plays, and gallops around the ends.

big point-scoring push in the third
quarter by prancing around left
end for 25 yards. He then added
30 yards with a toss to Atalaski.
But another attempted forward
failed and Hopkins came into possession of the ball.
An exchange of kicks resulted in
Petty pulling a Jay boot out of the
air on the 30-yard line and weaving
his way back to the 3-yard line before he was brought to earth. Hopkins held on the next two downs,
but on the third attempt, Andrews
was able to cross the goal line to
score a touchdown. •

Since Dr. Ames has occupied the president's chair, two new buildings
have arisen on the campus. The one, Levering Hall, was started during
Dr. Goodnow's term of office, but has opened under the new regime.
The other, the Physics Building, will be ready for occupancy in the next
few weeks. Several large endowments have been received, particularly
for the Medical School, by which the process of enlargement and construction is steadily progressing. New instructors have been added in
several departments of the college. More students are enrolling under
the New Plan; the Law Institute is spreading the reputation of Johns
Hopkins still farther.
The last named institution, the New Plan and the Law Institute, are
the projects which have devolved upon Dr. Ames to develop. Both
are new ideas, merely in their infancy. Both are so worthwhile that
they overshadow the college, which it must be remembered, is merely
a part of the great University over which Dr. Ames presides. The
New Plan, unlike the Law Institute, has found much opposition. It
has been contended that Hopkins will be an institution purely for the
specialized worker and that those merely searching for a general cultural education must suffer. Precisely. However, there are many colleges offering this general education, but only a few where the advanced
student will be able to derive as much advantage as at Hopkins. To
develop a school of scholars, that is the undertaking which confronts
Dr. Ames. The Law Institute, equally as great a project, has already
received the highest praise throughout the country. The jurists of the
country have long been bemoaning the multiplicity and stupidity of
some of our laws, but Hopkins has stopped talking about it; it is doing
something about it. These two great projects were begun under
President Goodnow ; they remain to be developed under President
Ames.

It would have been very strange had not the men of Hopkins desired
to see Dr. Ames in the executive chair. For in his years as Dean the
undergraduate body came to know Dr. Ames well, to highly respect
his judgment and friendly advice and to feel toward him that trust
which it is the fate of very few men to ever inspire.
Dr. Ames' years of loyal service to Johns Hopkins and his efforts
in aiding major items of the policy of the University undoubtedly were
two of the chief considerations which influenced the Board of Trustees
in his appointment. But it was Dr. Ames, the man, not Dr. Ames, the
administrator, who caused the undergraduates to appreciate so much
the decision of the Board. His ideals of fairness, with which he judged
each man and each situation, represents to the campus the highest
quality of a university official. It is a difficult position, this one of
governing the destinies of men in their formative period. While the
undergraduates appreciate Dr. Ames' administrative qualifications, they
esteem him more for his absolute fairness.

The new Institute of Law Building will be started sometime in the
next few months, according to Dr.
Cook. It will be open for use in
the fall of 1930, and the students
and professors will be ready to
start their work of Law Research
in the new building.
New Structure

A new structure is to be erected,
which cost $450,000. This will be
the home of the Institute of Law
and will be situated opposite the
Carrol mansion. This has been
made possible through the kindness
of an anonymous donor. The laboratories of the research workers
in law will consist of comfortable
studies.
Dr. Cook says, "the object of
the Institute will be to look into the
legal system of the United States
and find out whether or not our
laws prohibit the things which
should be prohibited and allow the
things which should be allowed."
The newly printed pamphlet of
the Institute, speaking of the Johns
Hopkins University says:
"It has commenced the two-fold
task, first of investigating the effect
of specific laws and legal procedures,
and, second, of securing knowledge
of economic and other conditions
which should influence the development of law."

Since Dr. Ames has occupied the president's chair, two new buildings
have arisen on the campus. The one, Levering Hall, was started during
Dr. Goodnow's term of office, but has opened under the new regime.
The other, the Physics Building, will be ready for occupancy in the next
few weeks. Several large endowments have been received, particularly
for the Medical School, by which the process of enlargement and construction is steadily progressing. New instructors have been added in
several departments of the college. More students are enrolling under
the New Plan; the Law Institute is spreading the reputation of Johns
Hopkins still farther.
The last named institution, the New Plan and the Law Institute, are
the projects which have devolved upon Dr. Ames to develop. Both
are new ideas, merely in their infancy. Both are so worthwhile that
they overshadow the college, which it must be remembered, is merely
a part of the great University over which Dr. Ames presides. The
New Plan, unlike the Law Institute, has found much opposition. It
has been contended that Hopkins will be an institution purely for the
specialized worker and that those merely searching for a general cultural education must suffer. Precisely. However, there are many colleges offering this general education, but only a few where the advanced
student will be able to derive as much advantage as at Hopkins. To
develop a school of scholars, that is the undertaking which confronts
Dr. Ames. The Law Institute, equally as great a project, has already
received the highest praise throughout the country. The jurists of the
country have long been bemoaning the multiplicity and stupidity of
some of our laws, but Hopkins has stopped talking about it; it is doing
something about it. These two great projects were begun under
President Goodnow ; they remain to be developed under President
Ames.
